Negatives  -Story portion is very short as it's merely the prologue/demo for the full game, The Phantom Pain -There's only a handful of other missions, and they take place in the same area -Can't use the mouse in menus (a minor blemish)  Gray area  -Some of the previous features are missing, such as knocking on walls and shaking down enemies for items, though this doesn't seem detrimental to the gameplay, and may even be a positive considering how simple and tight the controls are (though it's been a few years since I've played the others, so I cannot make a 100% accurate comparison) -Borderline being too spendy for how short the story portion is and the fact that all the other missions are in the same area and there's not many of them, but there's a solid amount of replayability regardless. This may or may not offend your sensibilities, but in my opinion it's worth the cost if you're not on a tight budget and find it on sale   Positives   -Gorgeous graphics -Stable and well-ported  -Tight and simple but not overly simplistic controls; feels very mechanically sound; takes some cues from games like Splinter Cell  -No count-down timers or radar make for a more tense, fun, and challenging experience -Useable vehicles -Sandbox -Non-linear setup allows for a variety of playing styles (i.e., stealthy, run-and-gun, etc)  All-in-all I give this a recommend if you find it in the $10-15 price range or lower. Though short, there's a few other missions that open once you finish the prologue, and the gameplay is rich and complex enough that it has a decent amount of replayability, the graphics are great, the sound is great, and it's a lot of fun.  It makes my Metal Gear... Solid.

There are bombs hidden in lady parts. 10/10  *Edit, 22/12/2014*   In all seriousness, this game screams quality. It goes to show that although PC gaming is thought as a small business investment in Japan, Konami really have gone all out to make this game shine on the Personal Computer. This “port” does not even seem to feel like it was created by a non-caring company that was only interested in your money; “Buy now, we fix it later”, but a well thought out, and developed game that has PC gamers in mind. Port: 10/10.  This game runs extremely well on many/any computer, despite it being on a small map, this comes as no surprise, BUT the model detail, and the amount of AI in your vicinity at once is still handled well on older computers. The AI itself is quite smart on the hard difficulty, although on normal they do feel fairly dumb.  The price can feel demanding for people that have heard there is only 20 minutes of content…Right, many people have said this is not true, but as many others have also said, it can be “completed in 5 minutes”. Let me clarify, both sides are wrong. The Ground Zeroes mission, the main mission, CAN be speed ran in <10 minutes, whereas the entire game (for completionists), can range from 5+ hours. There is quite a fair amount on content in Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes and a lot of people seem to forget that. The gameplay itself is very, very good. Although I, myself feel as if Kojima is keeping 99.9% of the gameplay mechanics (goodies) hidden well inside of The Phantom Pain’s unbeknownst release date. The way Big Boss moves, to the way combat is handled does not feel like a traditional Metal Gear Solid game. I am a long-time fan, and was at first sceptical about the way it looked from the trailers, it did not look “Metal Gear Solid” at all. Instead, it looked like DICE and Activision had teamed up and taken over development and decided; “we should make it appeal to all of the Battlefield and Call of Duty fans!” I could never have been more wrong. It DOES still feel like Metal Gear Solid, it just needs some getting used to. You have to remember the entire game itself is changing, the theme of the game has changed, the purpose of the game has changed. This is not Solid Snake. This is Big Boss. Playstation 2 players will remember how different Snake Eater felt compared to Metal Gear Solid, and Sons of Liberty. Big Boss is a different character, and has a different story. So what better to compliment his return to the game with new mechanics, a new engine, a new voice actor and a new tone of the series?  Overview:  Port: me, personally 10/10, but; 9/10 (Still heard some people are having loading problems)  AI: 8/10 (Normal difficulty is far too easy. Hard feels more enthralling)  Gameplay: 10/10 (Refreshing. Fast paced, slow paced. Stealthy or loud. Your choice)  Content: 8/10 (Not many missions, of course. But if you really want to 100% it, you may as well make a coffee and be ready for frustration) Voice Actors: 6/10 (I used to love the codec screens, and the voices that followed. No, I am not whining like most about Hayter being gone. Solid Snake is DONE. It was a mistake to make Big Boss’ voice actor Hayter in the first place. The guy is talented, as is Kiefer Sutherland, and I cannot fathom why the Japanese voice actor has been kept the same; but, Kiefer is the better choice. Why the 6, though? Because only select enemy soldiers have a voice actor. Most have the “Peace Walker subtitles” to serve as its way of giving you the information you got out of them. The only lines they have are notifying the command post of your presence, and shouting tactical orders, this is not fun, nor immersive…It just lacks any interest in what is going on. Plus, another negative is Skullface. His voice does not command leadership, nor does it sound “Villainous”, it just sounds plain. Environment: 5/10 (I could not come up with negatives nor positives for this, yes it is “open world” to a degree. If you count Camp Omega, and Camp Omega alone as open world. There is much to explore, and much to learn about where you can place yourself in certain situations, but the map still feels the same as the time before. I trust The Phantom Pain will rectify this, and deliver what I hope to be a 11/10 experience. Thank you for looking! Please do enjoy the game. If you are looking for a reason to buy it, you should not have to. It is worth every penny, and the series itself deserves every player, and it does not cost much? If you are still sceptical, just take a look at some YouTube videos.

Most games that have come out recently either had ridiculous fluctuating FPS, endless micro-stutter, and needed to be run on PC Gamer Life Support (Beta GPU drivers, file editing, bs life support software). For content: Look at all the posts about people spouting out the running gag 'paid demo hurrrr hurrrr' crap. You CAN get a lot of hours if you're into doing side-missions which are different enough to satisfy you, if you're looking for more. If this is a 'demo'? Then it's the best god damn demo you'll ever play!  EDIT: Oh, you'll have to control menus with WASD, ESC and Space. Following the Peace Walker incident, Big Boss now aims to save Chico (a child soldier in the Sandinista Liberation Front) and Paz (a young girl from Costa Rica) from a highly dangerous and guarded facility; Guantanamo Bay.   From the first few moments of the game, you are encouraged to scout the base, and understand your surroundings through the use of the binoculars and observation. Using that information the player can approach the game in many different ways, but mainly through stealth-- sneaking through the base, interrogating and eliminating silently the enemy or an all-out Commando re-enactment.   The stealth mechanics are an improved version from the ones in previous Metal Gear titles as elements such as light, dark, weather, position, and sound come into play for the detection system. Always wanted to play Metal Gear. My wishes have been fulfilled with Ground Zeroes. I have squeezed every ounce of gameplay from this prologue to The Phantom Pain, and to say that I'm waiting for September first is a massive understatement.   Edit/Update:   I believe it's time to actually state my impressions of this game in a bit more detail.  Right off the bat, the thing that Ground Zeroes nails perfectly is the level design. The map is just perfect in size, with different segments requiring proper planning and study of enemy movements in order to infiltrate stealthily. Now, the stealth in this game has been executed to near-perfection, and while you can go guns blazing - its much more satisfying if you are actually patient with the game and go with the stealthy approach. There will be a lot of trial and error involved, and granted that some may not be up for it, but you will develop a compulsion to perfect your playthrough. Think of it as the satisfaction that comes with nailing three purple sectors in a Formula 1 game. The level design of Ground Zeroes has a big part to play in this - it encourages you towards such a goal.  Another aspect of the game worthy of praise is the enemy AI. While individually the enemy is what you'd expect from a modern stealth game - each have their own routine within the area which they patrol, they look out for suspicious activities and check them out, one thing that sets them apart is that if possible, they always communicate via radio to the base HQ when they are about to perform some action that is beyond their normal routine - like checking out anything suspicious. This means that you have to track them till they radio back to HQ that things are fine. This adds to the immersion as you have to decide when to make a move on them - if you take them out when HQ expects some communication back from them, then the base will go on a level 1 alert, when nearby personnel are notified about the incident. Following this, if you are discovered, then the whole base goes on alert. This attention to detail leads to some very tense moments leading you to frantically search for cover or take the guards out carefully, as you're vulnerable out in the open especially on hard difficulty. That said, on rare occasions, the AI can be hilariously incompetent - once I was lying prone, perfectly still in tall grass when 3-4 guards were just a feet or two away and couldn't spot me. That's an exception though, not a norm.  Coming to the story, while it is clear that Kojima tackled something very politically charged in this game, I don't think he quite hit the target he aimed for. Even though this is my first Metal Gear game and I was willing to put aside all the things that happened in the previous games for the sake of concentrating just on this one, I must say that it wasn't as satisfying. For more details, check out youtuber Super Bunnyhop's impressions on the story of Ground Zeroes.  Oh, and the last thing - the optimization in this game is phenomenal. Considering how pleasing the graphics are, it took me by surprise that I could run it on my ancient 9-year-old PC with a Core 2 Duo CPU and a GT 730 DDR5. I left the settings at default with v-sync off at 1366x768 resolution and got 20-30fps throughout every mission. Say what you want about my standards of playability but I was absolutely fine with it. No crashes whatsoever.  Now I just need the time to get my hands on The Phantom Pain.

This, ladies and gentlemen, is how you do a port.  After spending nigh on 15 hours with the PS3 version, there was no doubt left in my mind that Ground Zeroes was worthy of being a Metal Gear Solid game. Say what you will about the length of the main mission, but this game clearly makes a case for the term 'content' being much more nuanced than how most people refer to it.  Camp Omega is the real star of the show in Ground Zeroes - feeling like an amalgamation of the very best levels from Thief, Hitman, and the Splinter Cell series in their heyday - and it reinforces how the stealth genre is more about the levels than anything else. Everything about Camp Omega feels like it was crafted by experts: The believable vantage points, the sparing-yet-dense use of both high and low grounds, the use of light and shadow, it's all there.  The PC version (both surprisingly and unsurprisingly) is the definitive way to play this game. The FOX Engine truly shines when left to flex its muscles on superior hardware. Seeing rainwater drip down the face of one of the many nameless soldiers I would chokehold into submission later on in the opening cutscene was the first sign of the capabilities of this new engine.  I feel like the bar has been raised impossibly high by Ground Zeroes as a prologue to the upcoming The Phantom Pain. If the levels in the full game can capture even a fraction of the craft seen on display in this game, it will be more than something special.

Pros:  -Amazing visuals. This is what a 'next-gen' game is supposed to look like. Hats off to Kojima's artists, they really earned their paychecks here. From the modelling, animations, texturing, etc. It all comes together beautifully.  -Tight controls. Gone are the days from older games where you had to check a menu just to figure out all sorts of button press combinations just to do semi-secret moves regarding CQC and such. It's been streamlined in a manner that's much more quick to pull off, without feeling overly trivialized.  -Solid gameplay. At no point did it ever feel janky or 'cheap'. Everything behaves in ways you ought to expect it, from how your character interacts with the environment, to the handling of weapons and the behaviour of your enemy.  -A couple of new tricks up Snake's sleeve. Interrogations and such are now a neat little thing.  -Lots of side-content. I didn't realize until I beat the game that you end up unlocking tons of side missions after the fact that you can play after, which is a good thing, because of a point I'll be getting to in the cons.   Cons: -It's short. Like. SUPER short. Way shorter than you'd think, even for a 15 dollar AAA game. If you knew what you were doing and didn't mind shooting your way through objectives, you could beat the entire 'main' game in 15-20 minutes easily. It took me roughly an hour and a half on my first playthrough, and that's because I went the wrong way initially and had to double back through the entire map.  -Stealth is kind of a joke. There isn't much punishment for getting spotted, and if you've ever played a third person shooter before, you can go guns blazing through this no problem. It's steath elements are merely a suggestion for the sake of challenge, rather than necessity, and thus, this isn't a real stealth game. This is action-adventure.  -Easy difficulty in general. There just isn't much in the way of punishment in this game, and it gives you too many means of just rambo'ing your way through should you mess up. Reflex time is a dumb addition clearly meant to hold the hands of newer players, but when you make such concessions, how do you expect new players to ever learn and improve? This little 'feature' can be turned off in options, but unfortunately it's on by default and you must go looking for it. Oh, did I also mention 'regenerating health' is now a thing? You can already bet your boots that Phantom Pain's online component is going to have unlock progression at this rate. Too many 'modern gaming industry' gimmicks sour the gameplay experience by removing all tension from stealth and combat.  -Ending cutscenes deprive you of interaction at some really cool segments. I wont drop any spoilers, but there will be points at the end when you scratch your head and ask yourself 'Why don't I get to play this part? Why am I watching the game have it's own fun?'  -Story wise, the game assumes you've played the more obscure titles on the PSP, a handheld that, frankly, not many people even owned in the first place. If games like Peacewalker were made available on consoles and PC, it would serve rather well to dispel some of the confusion of the plot that is loosely explained in text snippets that you have to look up on your own in the main menu outside of the in-game experience.  Overall:  I had a great deal of fun with this, even with some of it's shortcomings, they paled in comparison to the overall potential of the game. With only 8% completion after beating the 'main course', I've got a decent amount of replayability to knock out before I can truly write this game off as 'done'. While I'm not completely sold on this model of game distribution just yet due to how long it's taking to get Phantom Pain out, I can honestly say this game is worth the $14 dollar price tag it's asking for while on sale at the moment. On it's surface, it's got a 'demo' feel to it, but once you dive into some of the offered extra content, you're getting more bang for your buck than the typical 15 dollar indie zombie survival minecraft rip-off trite that gets regurgitated out of Greenlight at around this price range. I know one thing though: This game is a quantum-powered hype train for Phantom Pain. Once you make your way through this, the wait for the next stage of the franchise will be nearly unbearable, and thus, I have to fully recommend this game.

Ground Zeroes is the latest entry in the Metal Gear Solid saga. It's story takes place after the events of Metal Gear Solid 3, Metal Gear Solid Portable ops and Metal Gear solid Peace walker. This game is the first in the series to make use of the Fox engine, a completely new game engine aimed at creating a new generation of games. Gameplay wise this definitely shows, movement feels more controlled and enemies seem to move around more realistically. This does seem to make the game a lot harder then previous Metal Gear games (especially with reflex mode turned off) which is something people interested in this game should take into account.  Now to cover the inevitable elephant in the room when talking about this game: It's pretty short. The game has around 6 missions all taking place in the same area. However only one of those missions really matters to the story and depending on your skill can be finished in about half an hour, with the rest being more like bonus missions with true Kojimaesque eastereggs. Some argue that this makes the game a paid demo. Now I wouldn't go as far as to claim that myself, but story wise the game definitely leaves it's players hungry for more.  Speaking of which, another major controversy surrounding this game would be it's macabre ending. Now I won't spoil it for anyone reading this review since they likely haven't played the game yet, but needless to say this game isn't for the faint of heart. Which isn't necessarily bad however. As it elavates the games plot to a more mature level not seen before in videogames.  So would I recommend Metal Gear Solid Ground Zeroes? Yes, but if players feel they might be getting too little bang for their buck I would recommend them to get this game on sale.

THE SHORT REVIEW: As a fan of Metal Gear, this is a must-buy, but if your a first time Metal Gear person...it could be hit or miss.  THE LONG REVIEW: Ground Zeroes serves as the prologue to MGSV: The Phantom Pain, think of it as the appetizer before the main course. But boy oh boy it is actually one hell of a introduction that gets me excited for the full game. The first cutscene where it plays the song 'Here's to You' is done superbly, and THAT ENDING, wow, quite the cliffhanger.  To be completely honest I really wasn't expecting a whole lot for how long the game was, and I have to admit I was right in some regard. But where the game lacks in content, it will most likely make up in replay value. The open-ness of the level seems to draw me back and try different approaches, and seek out stuff I might've missed the first time.   The game itself is essentially an overglorified tech-demo, but an impressive one at that. As I said before, the game retains a high replay value because it's open, and the design feels very 'alive' to say the least. Should you come into contact with a guard, they will alert the whole base, and everyone will be on high alert. They'll be running around looking for you, and ready to shoot on sight until they've decided to give up the search. Unlike say Far Cry, the game feels less-scripted and more 'open' to the AI or player adapting to the environment.  If your new to Metal Gear, here might be an okay starting point, and I say this because it's one of the newer games, with the new mechanics and what not. You'll get into it, but going back and playing the previous games might be harder to do. So I'd suggest either getting caught up with the story, or going back and playing the older games because a lot of what's in here is mostly just tease for the next game for us fans.  Now preformance wise, it's worth noting that the PC version was extremely well optimized for me and my Nvidia, it ran at a high frame rate and was still able to look great, and I have to applaud for them actually making a really good PC version. Did I also mention that the game only takes up only about 4GB and still manages to look better than Titanfall and Call of Duty (which require 50+ GB of space)? This is how PC games are done.   Admittedly the price is still a tad steep even at $19.99 I'd say wait for it to drop in price before picking it up, because you don't really get $19 worth of content, in a sense the value is more in the replay than the actual play (but that could be argued). I'm not saying you have to avoid this entirely if you're getting into the franchise, but if you've had absolutely no experience with Metal Gear then chances are the game might not have the same flair for you.  MADE FOR: Fans wanting a taste of what's to come in The Phantom Pain  NOT MADE FOR: People expecting a full-fledged Metal Gear game  METAL GEAR SOLID V: GROUND ZEROES  8/10

Let me say this upfront: Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is NOT a full game. You can tell that it was initially a prologue level meant to be included WITH The Phantom Pain, but due to the need for (probably) more money for TPP's development, Konami forced it to be released as a separate title.   That being said, Ground Zeroes is not a BAD demo. The graphics are nothing short of fantastic, the gameplay is fluid, the enemy A.I. is intelligent and challenging, and the game runs superbly on almost all PC's. If you enjoy the stealth genre, this game will not disappoint you from a gameplay standpoint. Just be warned that if you're not a completionist, the main mission and accompanying 'Side-Ops' can be completed in less than three hours. You can only truly get your money's worth out of this game if you take the time to complete the missions on higher difficulties, achieve the coveted 'S-Rank' on each Op, collect all the cassette tapes, rescue all prisoners, and get all the achievements/XOF Patches. If those extra objectives interest you, then Ground Zeroes can take up many more hours of your time. I personally had a lot of fun replaying missions in this game, and I normally do not complete the games I play.

My first time beating the main mission took about one and a quarter hours, I can now do it in substancially less than that. However the gameplay is superb, there are a half-dozen side missions which are really quite varied, and the small base is dense. There are tons of conversations to overhear, equipment to pick up and a massive amount of tactical decison making to be done. Its not like many stealth games, including previous metal gears, where you have a couple paths and you choose one, there are a large number of options, and you really feel like you are following your own path. The AI is spectacular, if you are spotted a seach party is sent out and they fan the area. If a body is found they send reinforcements and if you destory a camera someone investigates. They also don't just pace in circles like robots, which goes a long way to raising the tension in the game.  Graphically it is easily the best looking game I have seen to date. Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes treads a thin line between tech demo and open-world sandbox   There’s been just one game that I finished in a single sitting, and that’s Metal Gear Solid IV: Guns of the Patriots on PS3. This fact is more a testament to the design of MGS IV than my unwavering commitment to the franchise. Let’s be clear: I’m not a Metal Gear Solid or Hideo Kojima fan boy. The reason it kept me hooked was the ebb and flow of the missions as well as even distribution of gameplay sections and long cut scenes (some long enough for you to consume entire meals while watching them like a TV show). But primarily it was the accessibility. MGS IV was a walk in the park compared to Ground Zeroes.   A QUESTION OF BREVITY   You’re probably aware of the biggest complaint people seem to have with Ground Zeroes. The game can be ‘beaten’ in around 20 minutes. If you’re looking to simply finish Ground Zeroes, it can be done with minimal to no effort at all, but bear in mind that you shouldn’t be playing it in the first place if that was your intention.  Ground Zeroes is a showcase. It is Kojima Productions experiment to craft an open-world with a difference—not one merely filled with side quests and characters to interact with, but one of an enormous scale in which you are free to explore everything without having to suspend disbelief. And by God, have they succeeded. It’s just a shame they’re asking you to pay $19.99/`1,200 for the recently released PC version. And while this is the definitive version of the game thanks to native 4K support and inclusion of bonus content from both Xbox and PlayStation versions, one can’t help but wonder if Kojima-san wanted to give away this game for free, and was promptly overruled by the evil corporate overlords at Konami who sniffed a revenue opportunity.   FOR THE COMPLETIONIST   After a trademark intro cut scene, you find yourself in the shoes of Big Boss with the task of extracting certain prisoners of war from an island prison. Do this successfully and you’ll open up extra missions and situations, as well as bonus objectives. For the completionist, Ground Zeroes is a wet dream, with different ways not just to beat missions but traverse the excellently designed sandbox of Camp Omega and discover something new every time you do it.  There’s a tonne of stuff here for fans (who have probably bought this anyway), but for those on the fence, there are several reasons to pick up Ground Zeroes. First, it’s the most complete stealth action game available today. None of the mechanics are watered down, it is intuitive but not accessible, and it’s mostly unforgiving to careless play. Guards may follow certain patrol routes, but they will surprise you with their intelligence and unpredictability on occasion. Get caught, and you’ll have once chance to headshot your potential captor—miss your chance and you’ll be in a spot of bother to say the least. MGS has been guilty of limiting gameplay scope, preferring to go down the cool-but-linear party tricks route, ‘meta’ gameplay and easter eggs. Ground Zeroes is the exact opposite, with a strong gameplay basis and true open-world mechanics.  However, you’re likely to get the most out of this only if you’re a hard-core MGS fan or find Splinter Cell too easy. For the rest, there are games out there with ten times the content Ground Zeroes offers, and with more variety (Far Cry 4, for instance). Without a doubt, I enjoyed Ground Zeroes, as I’m sure anybody who plays it will. But the game also makes you wonder at the type of company that charges ₹1306 for a demo.   My Rating: 7/10

The Metal Gear series has come a long way since the release of the first game in 1987. As someone who has played every single canon release, it's been interesting, entertaining, and sometimes frustrating dealing with the franchise's ups and downs. As a blueprint and teaser for what is to come, Ground Zeroes excels in terms of gameplay, story, atmosphere, and voice acting. Controls have been fine-tuned, the UI has been tweaked to create an immersive experience, AI has improved, and both the graphics and engine have set a new standard for AAA titles. I was also pleasantly surprised by Kiefer Sutherland's performance as Snake; he fits the role well and I definitely prefer him over David Hayter. The core experience is, pun intended, extremely solid. The only let down is the main mission's short length, and even though there are side ops set in the same environment, these will only satisfy completionists and score-chasers. It's best to wait for this title to go on sale before purchasing. That said, from the moment Snake pulls off his goggles and the camera turns to reveal the size and scale of the compound, an area larger than anything MGS has depicted before, Ground Zeroes flirts with greatness.

A much more classic Metal Gear experience than Phantom Pain, Ground Zeroes is Kojima offering to established fans of the series a chance to say goodbye to the Tactical Espionage Action era they once knew and loved. Campy and Bizarre moments are plentyful if you take the time to play the extra missions, which are really well thought out and, despite all being set on the same fairly small military base, are surprisingly different from one another.  For newcomers to the series, this is the tragic backstory that leads to Big Boss' transformation into 'Venom Snake'. This game caused controversy due to its audio depictions of (what is assumed to be) ♥♥♥♥, which was made integral to Ground Zeroes' story. Kojima's newly found commitment to ultra-realism just falls short of being truly convincing, the writing is good but still very Japanese which I think makes that particularly disturbing moment rather contrived and a little hamfisted.   This is nevertheless a game that succeeds in being poignant and insightful, and the gameplay successfully tows the line of innovation whilst retaining the feel of previous games. It does the latter better than Phantom Pain, but the filmic and striking Phantom Pain, of course, will always be the real MGS meat we were all wanting.  An essential purchase and a great and slightly different companion to Phantom Pain.

We'll start off with what's obvious from the get-go: This is a drop dead gorgeous game. It's beautiful. There are some really neat lighting effects and water looks great. Solid textures and some nice depth of field effects as well. It also runs terrifically on my setup. It's probably the single best PC port I've played since Splinter Cell Blacklist. It's a refreshing change in an industry that's given us duds like Assassin's Creed Unity that are hardly playable at high settings even on a strong setup like mine.  That being said, I have a number of complaints about the game. I finished in 4 hours. It's absurdly short, more a demo than anything.  In a lot of ways this franchise hasn't changed much since the second game, which is admittedly fine in some areas. I consider myself a longtime fan of the franchise -- Metal Gear Solid is probably one of my single favorite games of all-time. Fans of the series love the exclamation points, the cardboard boxes, and the weird, preachy stories. I'm no different. I love all that stuff, I eat it up. And it's important that the series doesn't lose its identity for the sake of progress. But there are some features of the series in this game that just plain haven't aged well, and that's where most of my complaints come from.  My biggest issue with the game comes from the foolish way checkpointing is laid out. Imagine you carefully and meticulously move halfway across an open yard of tents, taking care not to be spotted, only to slip up near the end due to hitting the wrong button. Now your last checkpoint forces to restart a football field (about 100 meters for our European friends) away and retrace your own steps. You also get to hear the same introductory codec message every single time, too. Not good.  Checkpointing is a holdover from older games that really does a lot to damage the experience here. There's no reason a semi-open world stealth title shouldn't have a save anywhere feature. Hell, the option to save via a codec message isn't even present in this game, so why even have checkpoints at all? It doesn't make sense to use them over a manual save function. This isn't even a question of save scumming, it's just a matter of modern convenience that Konami seems to have forgotten. I have the same issue with the Far Cry series. It's 2014. There's no excuse for these games to use checkpointing when they'd be far better served by utilizing a dynamic save system. Bad checkpoints are some of the most frustrating things in gaming, and it puzzles me that developers still use them when there are obviously better systems available. Seriously, checkpoints are down there with escort missions. Game developers: Kill them immediately. Please. I despise them in games, especially in stealth games.  I had some serious issues with the camera as well. There are times when you've got a roof or some kind of structure far over your head, and the camera needlessly zooms straight into the back of Big Boss's head. Why? It's nowhere near the ceiling. It doesn't work well with cover, either. It was frequently a pain to me when I would be creeping between small spaces, such a between cargo boxes or tents. I'd stop at a corner, move up into cover, and try to get a peek around the corner to see if a soldier was there. And more often than not, the camera would refuse to comply, just sitting closely behind Boss's head. They obviously knew that this was an issue because they included a shoulder switching camera mechanic, which rarely seems to do much. I was detected a few times simply because I was frustrated with the camera and decided I was sick of fooling with it, so I moved out. It's ridiculous to me that the camera is an issue in a game these days. I can't remember the last time I even had camera issues in a game at all. A poorly controlled camera is an issue that belongs 20 years ago in the N64 era. Not in a modern, next generation game. It's inexcusable.  Another holdover from the old games that seriously bothered me was the control scheme. There are menus within menus within menus when you've got a guard grabbed or when you want to customize weapons. You're holding a bumper, or flicking a stick, or pressing some random arbitrary button that just doesn't feel natural. The worst part about these menus is that there frequently is just no need for them. Games like Blacklist have featured the same types of things but made them vastly more simplified and intuitive. I find myself having to check the controls screen multiple times per session because I can't remember how to do something. That's a sign of having an unintuitive, overly complex, poorly designed control scheme. Movement, furthermore, is hampered by having a weird crawl/crouch/stand system, including a weird button to dive to the ground, which I didn't really understand or ever feel any need to use. Then there are a bunch more controls for when you're crawling. You can roll to the left. You can roll to the right. Hold a button to crawl more quickly. It's all just needlessly complex, and it feels tacked on when it's not really necessary.  There's no free climbing in this game like there is in other stealth games of the past few years -- And I'm not saying that it needs it. But movement in open-world or semi-open world stealth games like Blacklist, Dishonored, or Assassin's Creed, for example, has way more dimensions than it does in Ground Zeroes due to the distinct verticality in the form of climbing (or blinking, in Dishonored's case) up to platforms or roofs. It's nearly always present no matter where you are, and you know so intrinsically how to accomplish it that you don't have to think about it. Dishonored teaches you to blink once, and you've got it down. Assassin's Creed teaches you to free run once, and you remember. In Ground Zeroes, you can only really move up or down when there's a ladder present. Otherwise, you're moving simply on the ground, back and forth, to and fro. It doesn't have the verticality of those games. So why are the controls so damned complex and involved? It's how it's always been in the series, but with the advent of newer games with great traversal systems, Ground Zeroes' controls feature so many aspects that just seem totally unnecessary, and it only serves to muck everything up. I can't help but feel a simpler approach would have been far more successful here. Having an intuitive understanding of movement and being able to act without thinking is absolutely paramount in stealth games where being seen can lead to a very quick death, and I never feel like I have that down when I play this game. It's something that would come with practice, sure, but why should I have to practice at something that I can intrinsically pick up and do in pretty much every other game in the genre?  Look, I don't want Metal Gear to become Splinter Cell. I'm not saying that at all. But the step forward that Guns of the Patriots made in 2008 was excellent, and it breathed new life into the gameplay of the series and really saved it from becoming too dated. Gunplay was far better in that game. It was always wonky and unintuitive in the older games, with its weird go-to-first-person-and-then-aim thing. It never felt natural. You always felt like a bumbling idiot when you were trying to shoot somebody, and Solid Snake was supposed to be an expert with a firearm. Guns of the Patriots completely fixed that. They updated their gunplay to a more modern, third person shooter type system, and it worked fantastically. That is the type of step Konami needs to take with things like movement and checkpointing. Ground Zeroes, unfortunately, doesn't take that step. It just feels like a way prettier Guns of the Patriots. Which is certainly not a bad thing, and don't get me wrong: This is not a terrible game.  If you're a Metal Gear fan, buy it. You'll like it. But if you're just looking for a stealth experience, I'd heartily recommend Splinter Cell Blacklist over this game.

This game is one unfinished pile of junk, you can't even imagine. It's short, we all know that, but that's not the problem: if you have the audacity to release a 45 minute demo for over 20 bucks you better make god-f*cking-d*mn sure that the game is the most polished piece of software out there. But as you'd expect from a publisher like Konami these days it's not: this game is a bug ridden mess.  The savepoints are infuriating: they are invisibly scattered around the map, once you run into them you are basically stuck with this one and only point of saved progress: say for example you get spottet and sh*t's on fire and you just so happen to enter an autosafe-area; well you're dun goofed. There's no going back, if you are lucky you only wasted 10 minutes, on a bad day you are 30 minutes in and you have to restart the entire level.  The biggest joke tho is the way your gameplay IS ACTUALLY saved; you drive into an autosave with a truck? Well guess what; when you load the point you are suddenly standing in the open, close to an EMPTY truck. Even if you position yourself smart loading a savegame will 9/10 times spawn you in a completely different location (in roughly the same area) and 4 out of these 10 times that will be right in enemy line of sight; genius, GENIUS solution!  Next thing; again savepoint related. If you walk into an autosave-area 7/10 times Snake will just keep moving in the direction you were facing while entering that area. It's like a constant force pushing your character in an unwanted direction; always a nice touch in a hard-as-all-hell stealth game. In my 3 hours of play I had 6+ occasions where this happened; you have to exit to the menu-screen to get the unwanted movement unstuck.  Another issue are the controlls or rather the 'next-gen' contextual actions; often Snake will just lean on a wall or stick to cover when you try to move OUT of of cover or break away from it. Since timing is essential in this game, little things like that can ruin your run and are just plain out obnoxious.  The overall character movement animations are very well done but especially when laying down the disconnect between camera and player-model is not handled very well: Snake will swivel his upper body if you ready your weapon, basically staying in position while being able to look around 180°; but as soo as you go ADS the body aligns with the line of sight and your whole character model just turns instantly, sometimes snapping out of cover without you even noticing it. AGAIN; super stupid thing in a hardcore stealth game.  I would strongly reccomend to wait until the full game comes out and see if these issues are fixed, if not I can only really reccomend it to hardcore fans of the series.
